Types of Voids in Rocks- The figure illustrates different occurrences of voids in geological materials  - At the top: porous materials with intergranular pore space  - Porous media can be differentiated into well-sorted and poorly sorted materials  - Sorting controls pore connectivity and effective storage and flow properties  - At the bottom: fractured rock systems  - Examples include fractured bedrock and fracture networks in granite  - Also includes solution-enlarged features, typical for limestone and karst systems  - Void type strongly controls groundwater storage and flow behavior  - More detailed background is available in the free books provided by the Groundwater Project

The following unit introduces general types of motion. It is important to be aware that different concepts are available to describe motion in the unerground. Later units will transfer these concepts to groundwater related applications like solute transport and groundwater flow.

The terminology ‘types’ can also be considered as concepts. The terminology ‘motion’ comprise various processes like solute transport, groundwater flow, pressure transmission, and more. Focus of the unit is to provide an explanation about the general types of motion.

According to the balance equations, the flow or movement laws essentially form the "second pillar" for quantifying many processes in water management.Flow or movement laws describe the spreading processes of matter or energy.The spreading behavior depends on state variables such as pressure, temperature, or substance concentration. Flow or movement laws allow the determination of production and loss rates in a balance equation. Process quantification is thus based onbalance equations and low/movement laws.There are two important basic types of flow or movement laws in water management:"Convection type“"Diffusion type“In addition, there is a mixed form in the spread of dissolved substances in porous media. Frequently, both basic types act simultaneously on spreading processes (superposition). Initially, the above-mentioned basic types are treated separately.In the example (blue box / green arrow) it is important to acknowledge that several motion respectively flow processes occurgroundwater flow is described by the concept of diffusiondriven by gradientwithin a stationary medium (here the aquifer)tracer transport is described by the concept of advection (dispersion also occurs but can be neglected for that example)flow (transport) with the bulk movement of the carrying mediumthe carrying medium in that case is the groundwater (whereas groundwater flow – as mentioned – is described by the concept of diffusion)
Typical for advection (or bulk flow) is that the motion occurs with the moving carrier

Konvektion (oder Advektion) ist der Transport von Materie oder Energie mit der Bewegung eines strömenden Mediums. Das strömende Medium kann als Trägermedium bezeichnet werden und ist i. d. R. ein Fluid. Beispiele:                                                                                                                                   – Konvektion von Wärme bei der Warmwasserheizung, im Golfstrom oder bei der Luftbewegung (Thermik beim Segelfliegen)                                                 – Advektion von gelösten (Schad-)Stoffen oder suspendierten Partikeln in Gewässern, im Grundwasser oder mit dem WindTendenziell wird der Begriff „Konvektion“ eher beim Energietransport (insbesondere Wärme), der Begriff „Advektion“ eher beim Massen- oder Volumentransport verwendet.
The diffusion type of motion is movement of matter or energy based on the physical concept of diffusion.

Fundamentals of the "Diffusion Type"The "Diffusion Type" describes the transport of matter or energy within a stationary medium.In contrast to convection, mass or energy transport in this case is not tied to the movement of a carrier medium.Examples:Heat conduction in solids (such as irons or stovetops)Diffusion of dissolved substances in stationary fluidsElectric current in conductors or semiconductors (electrostatics)Flow of water in porous media (infiltration or groundwater flow)

Basic principles of diffusion (cause by Brown’s molecule movement)Important to note that Diffusion coefficients in free water are quite smallThe negative sign indicates that the movement is from greater to lesser concentrations. Note the analogies to Darcy's law (hydraulic flow), Ohm's law (charge transport), and Fourier's Law (heat transport)Diffusion can lead to a spread of a contaminant in absence of a hydraulic gradient, i.e. if the groundwater is not moving, simply due to a concentration gradient (cf. there is no velocity / discharge term in the equation!)Diffusion is slow, yet can be significant over long periods of timeDiffusion can also affect water in voids which are too small to be significant in flow processes “effective porosity” (i.e. in immobile water trapped in small pore radii)

Flow and Motion Laws in Water ManagementAccording to balance equations, flow and motion laws form the "second pillar" for quantifying many processes in water management.Flow and motion laws describe the spread of matter or energy.The behavior of spreading depends on state variables such as pressure, temperature, or substance concentration.Flow and motion laws allow the determination of production and loss rates within a balance equation.Process quantification is therefore based on balance equations and flow/motion laws.Two Fundamental Types of Flow and Motion Laws in Water Management:"Convection Type""Diffusion Type"Additionally, a hybrid form exists for the spread of dissolved substances in porous media.Often, both fundamental types act simultaneously in spreading processes (overlapping effects).Initially, these two types will be examined separately.

The total volume of water on Earth amounts to ca. 1 358 710 150 km³ (≈ 1018 m³).The total volume of fresh water on Earth amounts to ca. 38 000 000 km³ (≈ 1016 m³).

The hydrological balance provides a relationship between various flow rates for a certain area. It is based on the conservation of water volume.expressed in words:  inflow equals outflow plus change in storageexpressed by an equation:change in storage ΔS > 0:                                                                                                Water volume is increasing with time in the investigation area.change in storage ΔS < 0:                                                                                                 Water volume is decreasing with time in the investigation area.change in storage ΔS = 0:                                                                                                     Water volume does not change with time in the investigation area (steady-state or stationary situation, i.e. inflow equals outflow).

Inflow and outflow may each consist of several individual components.ΔV = 0 (no change in  volume) is tantamount to steady-state or stationary (= time-independent) conditions.For steady-state conditions we have: Qin = Qout

Inflow and outflow may each consist of several individual components.ΔM = 0 (no change in mass) is tantamount to steady-state or stationary (= time-independent) conditions.For steady-state conditions we have: Jin = Jout

Mass and volume budgets are equivalent if there is no change of density  [M/L³] with time. In this case the well known relationship ΔM = ·ΔV holds and each equation given above can be directly transformed into the other one.If density changes have to be considered (e.g. for gas flow), the mass budget equation remains valid but the volume budget equation must be modified because ΔM = ·ΔV + Δ·V with Δ = change in density.Cases with changing density have proven to be more easily tractable if the mass budget equation is used.
